Award.AwardTitle: Convex Bodies in Algebraic Geometry and Representation Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Kaveh will work on problems in the interface of algebra, geometry and combinatorics. The central theme of the proposal is to associate convex bodies to projective algebraic varieties such that important information about the geometry of the variety can be read off from the associated convex body. Introduced in passing by Okounkov, this construction generalizes the well-known and extremely rich correspondence between geometry of toric varieties and combinatorics of convex polytopes. The proposal will apply this technique to prove new results and introduce new constructions and examples in areas such as: symplectic geometry and integrable systems, non-commutative algebra and algebraic geometry, and representation theory of reductive algebraic groups. The strength of combinatorial techniques available for toric varieties makes them very useful in several areas among which are mirror symmetry in mathematical physics and computational algebra. The project, in particular, is hoped to contribute to far extending the scope of toric methods.

Algebraic geometry, one of the oldest and most central areas of mathematics, is concerned with the geometric study of solutions of polynomial equations in several variables. It interacts with many other fields ranging from representation theory to topology, complex analysis, combinatorics and number theory. It has important applications to problems in areas as diverse as cryptography, coding theory and high energy physics. The particular problems Kaveh will study involve interaction between geometry/combinatorics of solids in space, and geometric objects defined by systems of polynomial equations. He hopes this work will lead to development of some valuable new techniques in algebraic geometry and related fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Polynomials and their solution sets play a major role in mathematics and all its areas of application such as physics, engineering and biology. A polynomial is given by its set of expoenents and the corresponding coefficients. In the Newton polyhedra theory (whose origins go back to Sir Issac Newton) one observes that there is a connection between the geometry of the solution set of the polynomial and the convex polytope constructed from the set of exponents of the polynomial. This is a starting point for the so-called toric geometry, a well-known and extremely useful part of algebraic geometry. It has numerous applications ranging from high energy physics to computational algebra.

The main goal of the project was to vastly generalize the methods from toric geometry and make a connection between algebraic geometry and convex geometry in a very general setup. This is the subject of the theory of Newton-Okounkov bodies. It was named after Andrei Okounkov (recipient of Fields Medal in 2006, also known as the Nobel Prize of mathematics). This is a recent theory with many open questions. The project was one of the first projects that aimed to develop this theory further and answer some important questions. This theory makes it possible to apply methods similar to those in toric geometry to a much larger setting.

The project was highly successful and the PI and collaborators managed to answer completely some of the main problems proposed in the project. It resulted in 7 research papers some of which have appeared in the highest ranking mathematical journals. The project explored different aspects of this theory related to geometry, algebraic geometry and representation theory.

More specifically, the PI and his collaborator Megumi Harada successfully finished a project which gives a general connection between algebraic geometry, convex geometry and theory of Hamiltonian actions and integrable systems (from classical mechanics). This work was very well received by the algebra/geometry community and appeared in Inventiones Mathematicae.

Representation theory is one of the major branches of algebra with intimate connections with modern physics specially quantum mechanics.  The PI also finished a project about a connection between representation theory, convex polytopes and algebraic geometry. This work also got attention from representation community and has appeared in Duke Mathematical Journal. 

Other works finished in the project were about connections between convex polytopes and multiplicities of solutions of systems of algebraic equations as well as geometry of spherical varieites extending well-known theorems form toric geometry. These works are joint with A. G. Khovanskii.

The PI and his collaborator A. G. Khovanskii continue to work on a book on the subject, namely the theory of Newton-Okounkov bodies. The material should be accessible to good graduate students in algebra and geometry. Also the PI taught two courses in algebraic geometry with some emphasis on appearnaces of convex polytopes in algebraic geometry. Brief lecture notes can be found on the PI's webpage.
